<u>Foliation <s>distinct<\s> different from stratification.
In the chapter already <s>[text?]<\s> quoted Mr
Darwin has combated the opinion prevailing among
geologists "with respect to the origin of the folia
of quartz, mica <s>&<\s> felspar & other minerals com-
posing the metamorphic Schists, that the constituent
parts of each were separately deposited as sediment
and then metamorphosed"+. Nevertheless that opinion
still appears to hold its ground & has been lately
re-asserted in a publication of high authority.xx
The remarks already <s>given<\s> made on the analogy
between foliation & cleavage <s>strengthen<\s> confirm Mr. Darwin’s
view that “ foliation & cleavage are parts of the
same process;” for on no other supposition can
we explain the conformity between the two where
seen in contact & their being combined in the
same arch of elevation. Now as cleavage is
almost always transverse to the bedding & obviously
a change produced in the beds after their deposition
it follows that foliation also is distinct from
bedding or sedimentary stratification. 
+ Geological Observations on South America, p. 165.
xx Sir C. Lyell’s Manual of Elementary Geology,
London, 1851, where the arguments for the sedimentary
origin & subsequent metamorphism of Gneiss, Mica
Schist &c are produced at great length, & their structure
is represented as <u>stratification<\u> & nowise related to
cleavage, pp. 467 to 481.
